awd_titl_txt: CRII: CSR: Energy-Aware Coordination and Management of Multi-Purpose Autonomous Robots for Maintained Continuity of Operations and Long Battery Lifetime.
awd_abstract_narration:
Autonomous Robot (AR) fleets will soon assist humans for the execution of several tasks. One of the most important factors that will likely affect the widespread adoption of AR fleets in our society is their ease of management for the end users. The goal of this project is to achieve the easy management of the AR fleet by allowing end users to indicate the set of tasks to execute during a working period and by implementing algorithms that automatically (i) allocate tasks to ARs, (ii) coordinate recharge schedules, (iii) ensure continuity of operations, and (iv) minimize the battery degradation. 

The intellectual merits of this project are focused on designing an AR fleet manager system that can be used by end users to interact easily with an AR fleet. Three main research thrusts are: (i) joint optimization of concurrent tasks allocation and recharge scheduling for ARs to minimize the task downtime and battery degradation during the working period; (ii) coordination of the ARs' computing and sensing resources to balance tasks performance and energy consumption; (iii) full system implementation and experimentation on a small-scale physical testbed and a large-scale simulated testbed. 

The proposed work will introduce new technologies available for the management of AR fleets and boost the widespread use of autonomous robots in our society, e.g., homes, smart farms, industry, and smart cities. The project will provide a new hardware and software testbed to help train and inspire undergraduate and graduate students. New industry collaborations will be established to enhance AR adoption. New academic collaborations will also be established with researchers in various areas including robotics, artificial intelligence, control systems, sensing, and approximation algorithms. 

All the new algorithms and the experimental results generated as part of the proposed project will be distributed in the form of journal articles, conference proceedings, workshops, invited presentations, and student thesis. In addition, the data, source code, simulators, and hardware details will be maintained on a dedicated research website (http://brok.eng.wayne.edu/AFM.html). This repository will be retained and maintained for at least five years after the completion of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have developed an Autonomous robots Fleet Manager, which jointly considers the problem of minimizing the downtime of computational task execution and the battery lifespan degradation for a fleet of Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs). This is the first study conducted to address the problem of how to trade off task performance and battery lifespan for battery-powered computing systems. Our specific objectives were to develop an Integrated Task Allocation and Charging Manager (TCM), and a per-robot power manager. TCM runs on a local server node. It periodically updates the task allocation on the AMRs and their recharge schedule to ensure continuity of operations for the remaining working period while preserving the batteries' lifetime. On each AMR, the power manager runs at a finer time grain than TCM to modulate the computing speed and the robot speed so that the tasks performance is maximized under a power cap indicated by the TCM. In addition, the project helped building a small-scale fleet of AMRs in the Energy-aware autonomous systems lab of the PI and to explore collaborations on battery lifespan-aware sensor networks, collaborative battery-based vehicle computing, and real-time systems.

We have designed TCM, a polynomial time algorithm that allocates tasks and schedules charges to minimize downtime while maximizing the battery life quality of an AMR fleet. Its decisions are affected by a weight parameter that allows users to choose the importance on the battery life quality target over task allocation performance. 

We have studied how to handle fault tolerance by scheduling preventive robot maintenance and by leveraging task replication for task allocation. For the first approach, we handle the high problem complexity by designing an algorithm based on linear programming and a variant of Hungarian method to schedule robot maintenance and to optimally allocate tasks/charging for each robot. For the second approach, we have designed a framework for energy-aware resource management in collaborative autonomous vehicle computing systems. The framework is composed of two algorithms: (i) a resource selector algorithm that determines which vehicles can share their resources for task allocation and improved fault tolerance over an optimized sharing period; and (ii) an energy manager algorithm that determines the task allocation across vehicles and how many replicas to use for each task with the aim of minimizing the computational energy consumption while satisfying a desired risk factor.

We have worked on how to provide real-time guarantees considering a system of primary-secondary processor, where the primary processor is mainly used but can offload tasks to the secondary processor when deadlines would be missed. This is applicable to many autonomous systems, including robots, where multiple computing units are available either on board or remotely. 

To further investigate the opportunity of using edge servers assisting the navigation software of autonomous robots/vehicles, we have also worked on studying how heterogeneous edge computing systems affect their navigation speed. Specifically, we have studied how robot/vehicle safe speed and travel time on a selected path is affected by deploying different amounts of resources in different areas where autonomous vehicles/robots operate. The insights and findings of this study will inspire new research that can considerably speed up the deployment of edge-assisted autonomous mobile systems in our society.

We have built and programmed three autonomous mobile robots, which are now able to autonomously navigate an indoor environment with fixed and moving obstacles. Using this fleet, we have collected data on energy consumption and timeliness of navigation task execution to determine how to best use the energy budget provided by TCM while maximizing task performance and safety. In particular, we have used the collected data to design a lightweight imitation learning-based control system that dynamically decides computing frequency and robot speed directly on the robot for optimized performance. 

In relation to battery lifespan-aware computing, we have worked on a network protocol able to trade off performance of packet transmission for longer battery lifespan in energy-harvested sensor nodes. The work was tested in both simulation and real environment.

We have involved two PhD students as well as four undergraduate students in this project, including two female underrepresented students. We have published the above research in IEEE International Conference on Autonomic Computing and Self-Organizing Systems (ACSOS), IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, IEEE International Conference on Embedded Software and Systems (ICESS), and some, at the time of writing, are being reviewed by IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems and other reputable conferences. We will leverage the small-scale autonomous mobile robot fleet and the gained experience to conduct further research on environmental sustainability of battery-based autonomous systems. We have created a website for the project and made our TCM implementation open source and downloadable from github.
